title: Hailes Abbey Walking Route

images.title: Philip Halling / Hailes Abbey
images.caption: Hailes Abbey was founded in 1246 and was once a site of pilgrimage. Like many others this Cistercian abbey was desolved in the reformation during the reign of king Henry VIII. The abbey is in the care of the National Trust.

images.title: neil hanson, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Hailes Abbey ruins.

images.title: Jonathan Billinger / Hailes church
images.caption: Hailes church. The church does not appear to have a dedication. The building predates the 12th century Cistercian Abbey nearby by 50 years.

images.title: Philip Halling / Hailes Abbey
images.caption: Possibly the remains of a cross situated to the west of Hailes Abbey which can be seen in the background.

images.title: Philip Halling / Hailes Labyrinth
images.caption: Hailes Labyrinth. The grass Hailes Labyrinth is highlighted by frost.

images.title: Michael Dibb / Cottages on Salters's Lane
images.caption: Cottages on Salters's Lane

description: This circular walk visits the historic Hailes Abbey in Gloucestershire. It then uses a section of the Gloucestershire Way to visit the nearby town of Winchcombe. As such the route could also be started/finished from the town if your prefer. The route runs for about 7 miles, exploring the countryside surrounding the abbey. It starts and ends at the abbey car park, located next to Hailes Wood about two miles north east of Winchcombe. The ruined abbey dates back to 1246 is and is designated as a Grade I listed building. It is now under the care of English Heritage and includes a fascinating museum where you can learn all about the abbey's history. You can extend the walk by heading a little to the south to visit the neighbouring Sudeley Castle, another highlight of the area.

details.subtitle: Further Information and Other Local Ideas
details.content: The Cotswold Way National trail passes the site, providing an opportunity for further exploring the area. For more walking ideas in the area see the Gloucestershire Walks, Cotswolds Walks page.

display_address: Stanway, Hailes, Tewkesbury, Gloucestershire, England, GL54 5PB, United Kingdom
